oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small broadside advertising Stone and Robinson Flour Mill at Oak Hill, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Handbills; Fliers (printed matter); Posters; Grains; Food industry; Toll roads
Flour mills; Fayetteville (Tenn.); Lincoln County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Fayetteville Observer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A gristmill or grist mill is a building where grain is ground into flour, or the grinding mechanism itself. In many countries these are referred to as corn mills or flour mills. Classical mill designs are usually water powered, though some are windmills, or powered by livestock. The millstones themselves turn at around 120 rpm. They are laid one on top of the other. The bottom stone, called the bed, is fixed to the floor, while the top stone, the runner, is mounted on a separate spindle.
